posts.name: Ibrahim
posts.cooked: Our team intends to use a bumper mounting system similar to 2910’s w/ captured nuts and bolts and I noticed that in their cad model there is is the long section between their swerve modules that does no have any standoffs for support, but according to the bumper construction rules, the bumper needs to be supported at least every 8 inches, does the aluminum tube as part of the bumper count as support?

posts.name: Wes
posts.cooked: There is a tube that goes in between the swerve modules, holding the robot together. Anything attached to the bumper dose not count as support.

posts.name: Ibrahim
posts.cooked:
But the posts the 1x1 is sitting would count as supports, right, and the posts are only 2 or 3 on the swerve modules and there is a long section greater than 8in with no posts underneath Screenshot 2023-02-02 072049 510×538 150 KB

Screenshot 2023-02-02 072049 510×538 150 KB

Screenshot 2023-02-02 072049 510×538 150 KB

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
In this case, the plates for the swerve modules are structural and count as supports, as does the tubing between them.  The bumper is fully supported along it’s entire edge.

Note that even if the bumpers are mounted a little high, the frame still runs the full length behind them along the bottom half of the bumper.

posts.name: Andrew H.
posts.cooked:
In my experience, “bumper support” only cares the plywood of the bumpers is resting against the hard parts of the frame. For the image shown, the bumpers are resting snugly against the frame everywhere, so there are no gaps in direct support. According to the rules, there is a 1/4" tolerance for “resting against” before a section of bumper is not directly supported. Then, there is an allowance for sections no more than 8" long to be unsupported.

Note that this definition does not stipulate or care about where/how bumpers are attached to the robot. It’s perfectly fine–and quite common–for wrap-around bumper to attach to the robot at only four points. Conversely, a section of bumpers which is attached by bolts to the frame every 2", but with a 1/2" gap between the plywood and robot frame, would not pass inspection without fixing the gap.

The height of the attachment points also does not matter, as long as it stays in the bumper zone. In fact the only regulations regarding attaching the bumpers is that they must be secure and easy to remove.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Andrew H. | FRC 1506 Alum | Scouting Enthusiast

posts.custom_user_title: Andrew H. | FRC 1506 Alum | Scouting Enthusiast

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: This rule is saying there is something “behind” the bumpers.   An example of something which would be illegal would be: say you built a U-shaped robot with a 10" opening and then decided you didn’t like that and wanted a square robot so you just put a solid bumper all the way around the robot, including across the 10" opening of the U.  That’s more than 8" unsupported (from behind) and thus not allowed.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
I think the confusion you are having is that you are thinking of support in the vertical sense. What the rule R410 is talking about (in terms of no more than an 8" gap) is support in the horizontal sense. You will notice that in diagram 9-9 directly below rule R410, you are looking down onto the robot from above.

The support they are worried about here is relative to impacts when two robots run into each other. So the plywood will be pushed toward the robot frame and if the gaps in the frame were too big, the plywood might break and the robot would no longer be protected.

In the CAD images that you posted, there is a full length frame member as well as the upper and lower plates of the swerve modules that provide this horizontal “support” for the bumpers.

The corner studs that provide the vertical support are not what the rule is talking about. The only thing that governs how many of those vertical supports you need is really more about maintaining the bumpers in the bumper zone. In theory you could do this with 3 supports (3 points define a plane) but most teams have at least one support per side or corner since those are locations on the robot that are easy to put an attachment point. Some teams might have 2 or more attachments on some or all of the sides. But none of that is to address the “support” talked about in R410.

I hope that clears it up for you.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Please note that the bumper construction rules are the minimum needed to pass inspection.  There are some game rules to also be aware of:

G101 *Dangerous ROBOTS: not allowed.    – unlikely your bumpers violate this, but listed here for completeness.  Penalty: DISABLED (see below)

G103 *Keep your BUMPERS low.  – if your bumpers are insufficiently constrained you could violate this during a match. Penalty:  FOULs if repeated or non-momentary

G104 *Keep your BUMPERS together – if your bumpers are not well constructed this could be a big problem. Penalty: robot DISABLED (which likely loses you the match and causes other teams to not want to select you for their alliance in eliminations)
